<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-visualization-function-for-ensemble-approach" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#visualization-function-for-ensemble-approach"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Visualization function for Ensemble approach</h3>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#' This function generates a comprehensive plot with all the time series forecast RMSE or SMAPE values for the Ensemble method. 
#' @param dfa: ARIMA/ARMA data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.
#' @param dfm: MLP data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.
#' @param type: RMSE or SMAPE
#' @param period: Time interval of the realization. Could take values: 'M' - Monthly data; 'Q' - Quarterly data; 'Y' - Yearly data  

e_visualize = function(dfa, dfm, type, period)
{ 
  y_label = toupper(type)
  period = toupper(period)
  
  if (period == 'M') {period = 'Monthly data'}
    else if (period == 'Q') {period = 'Quarterly Data'}
    else if (period == 'Y') {period = 'Yearly Data'}
  
  ggplot(dfa, aes(x, value)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = MODEL)) +
  geom_line(data = dfm, aes(color = MODEL), linetype = &quot;dashed&quot;, linewidth = 1) +
  xlab(&quot;Forecast horizion&quot;) + ylab(y_label) +
  labs(title=&quot;ARIMA vs MLP Ensemble model performance&quot;,
       subtitle = period)+
  theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust=0.5))
}"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' This function generates a comprehensive plot with all the time series forecast RMSE or SMAPE values for the Ensemble method. </span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param dfa: ARIMA/ARMA data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param dfm: MLP data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param type: RMSE or SMAPE</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param period: Time interval of the realization. Could take values: 'M' - Monthly data; 'Q' - Quarterly data; 'Y' - Yearly data  </span>

<span class="pl-en">e_visualize</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>, <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>, <span class="pl-smi">type</span>, <span class="pl-smi">period</span>)
{ 
  <span class="pl-v">y_label</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> toupper(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>)
  <span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> toupper(<span class="pl-smi">period</span>)
  
  <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">period</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>M<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) {<span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Monthly data<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>}
    <span class="pl-k">else</span> <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">period</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Q<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) {<span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Quarterly Data<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>}
    <span class="pl-k">else</span> <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">period</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Y<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) {<span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Yearly Data<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>}
  
  ggplot(<span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>, aes(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>, <span class="pl-smi">value</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
  geom_line(aes(<span class="pl-v">color</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">MODEL</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
  geom_line(<span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>, aes(<span class="pl-v">color</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">MODEL</span>), <span class="pl-v">linetype</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>dashed<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">linewidth</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
  xlab(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Forecast horizion<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> ylab(<span class="pl-smi">y_label</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
  labs(<span class="pl-v">title</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>ARIMA vs MLP Ensemble model performance<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,
       <span class="pl-v">subtitle</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">period</span>)<span class="pl-k">+</span>
  theme(<span class="pl-v">plot.title</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>element_text(<span class="pl-v">hjust</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>),
        <span class="pl-v">plot.subtitle</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> element_text(<span class="pl-v">hjust</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>))
}</pre></div>

<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-faceted-ggplot-by-horizon-for-easy-performance-comparison-between-arima-and-mlp" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#faceted-ggplot-by-horizon-for-easy-performance-comparison-between-arima-and-mlp"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Faceted ggplot by horizon for easy performance comparison between ARIMA and MLP</h3>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#' This function takes advantage of the ggplot facet_grid function and generates a plot for forecast RMSE or SMAPE values divided up by horizon factor. 
#' @param dfa: ARIMA/ARMA data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.
#' @param dfm: MLP data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.
#' @param type: RMSE or SMAPE
#' @param period: Time interval of the realization. Could take values: 'M' - Monthly data; 'Q' - Quarterly data; 'Y' - Yearly data

facet_visualize = function(dfa, dfm, type, period)
{ 
  y_label = toupper(type)
  period = toupper(period)
  
  if (period == 'M') {period = 'Monthly data'}
    else if (period == 'Q') {period = 'Quarterly Data'}
    else if (period == 'Y') {period = 'Yearly Data'}
  
  type=toupper(paste(type,'_',sep=''))
  a_horizon_labels = unique(dfa$Horizon_ARIMA)
  dfah = as.numeric(gsub(type, &quot;&quot;, a_horizon_labels))
  a_horizon_category = as.factor(gsub(type, &quot;&quot;, dfa$Horizon_ARIMA))
  dfa['h_factor'] = a_horizon_category
  dfa['model'] = 'ARIMA'
  dfa = dfa[ , -which(names(dfa) == &quot;Horizon_ARIMA&quot;)]
  
  m_horizon_labels = unique(dfm$Horizon_MLP)
  dfmh = as.numeric(gsub(type, &quot;&quot;, m_horizon_labels))
  m_horizon_category = as.factor(gsub(type, &quot;&quot;, dfm$Horizon_MLP))
  dfm['h_factor'] = m_horizon_category
  dfm['model'] = 'MLP'
  dfm = dfm[ , -which(names(dfm) == &quot;Horizon_MLP&quot;)]
  
  merged_dataset = rbind(dfa,dfm)
  
  ggplot(data = merged_dataset, aes(x, value)) +
    geom_line(mapping = aes(linetype = model, group = model, color = model)) +
    facet_grid(. ~ h_factor) + 
    xlab(&quot;# of models&quot;) + 
    ylab(y_label) +
    labs(title=&quot;Faceted ARIMA vs MLP model performance&quot;,
         subtitle = period) +
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5),
          plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust=0.5))
}"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' This function takes advantage of the ggplot facet_grid function and generates a plot for forecast RMSE or SMAPE values divided up by horizon factor. </span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param dfa: ARIMA/ARMA data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param dfm: MLP data frame generated by the `dataprep()` function as an output.</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param type: RMSE or SMAPE</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param period: Time interval of the realization. Could take values: 'M' - Monthly data; 'Q' - Quarterly data; 'Y' - Yearly data</span>

<span class="pl-en">facet_visualize</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>, <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>, <span class="pl-smi">type</span>, <span class="pl-smi">period</span>)
{ 
  <span class="pl-v">y_label</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> toupper(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>)
  <span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> toupper(<span class="pl-smi">period</span>)
  
  <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">period</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>M<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) {<span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Monthly data<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>}
    <span class="pl-k">else</span> <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">period</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Q<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) {<span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Quarterly Data<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>}
    <span class="pl-k">else</span> <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">period</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Y<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) {<span class="pl-v">period</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Yearly Data<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>}
  
  <span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>toupper(paste(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>_<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,<span class="pl-v">sep</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))
  <span class="pl-v">a_horizon_labels</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> unique(<span class="pl-smi">dfa</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Horizon_ARIMA</span>)
  <span class="pl-v">dfah</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.numeric(gsub(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">a_horizon_labels</span>))
  <span class="pl-v">a_horizon_category</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.factor(gsub(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">dfa</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Horizon_ARIMA</span>))
  <span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>h_factor<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">a_horizon_category</span>
  <span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>model<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>ARIMA<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
  <span class="pl-v">dfa</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>[ , <span class="pl-k">-</span>which(names(<span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>) <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Horizon_ARIMA<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)]
  
  <span class="pl-v">m_horizon_labels</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> unique(<span class="pl-smi">dfm</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Horizon_MLP</span>)
  <span class="pl-v">dfmh</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.numeric(gsub(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">m_horizon_labels</span>))
  <span class="pl-v">m_horizon_category</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.factor(gsub(<span class="pl-smi">type</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Horizon_MLP</span>))
  <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>h_factor<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">m_horizon_category</span>
  <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>model<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>MLP<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
  <span class="pl-v">dfm</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>[ , <span class="pl-k">-</span>which(names(<span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>) <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Horizon_MLP<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)]
  
  <span class="pl-v">merged_dataset</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> rbind(<span class="pl-smi">dfa</span>,<span class="pl-smi">dfm</span>)
  
  ggplot(<span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">merged_dataset</span>, aes(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>, <span class="pl-smi">value</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
    geom_line(<span class="pl-v">mapping</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> aes(<span class="pl-v">linetype</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">model</span>, <span class="pl-v">group</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">model</span>, <span class="pl-v">color</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">model</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
    facet_grid(<span class="pl-smi">.</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">h_factor</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> 
    xlab(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span># of models<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> 
    ylab(<span class="pl-smi">y_label</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
    labs(<span class="pl-v">title</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Faceted ARIMA vs MLP model performance<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,
         <span class="pl-v">subtitle</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">period</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span>
    theme(<span class="pl-v">plot.title</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>element_text(<span class="pl-v">hjust</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>),
          <span class="pl-v">plot.subtitle</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> element_text(<span class="pl-v">hjust</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.5</span>))
}</pre></div>

<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-non-parametric-wilcoxon-rank-sum-test" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#non-parametric-wilcoxon-rank-sum-test"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Non-parametric Wilcoxon rank sum test</h3>
<p dir="auto"><math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="ecab1d4582ee8dcb646a26026955c212">$H_0 = 0$</math-renderer> (The median of ARIMA RMSE = The median of MLP RMSE)<br>
<math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="ecab1d4582ee8dcb646a26026955c212">$H_a \ne 0$</math-renderer> (The median of ARIMA RMSE <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="ecab1d4582ee8dcb646a26026955c212">$\ne$</math-renderer> The median of MLP RMSE)
########################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#' This function computes a Wilcoxon hypothesis test between ARIMA/ARMA and MLP RMSE distributions to see if the forecast errors are significant or not. 
#' Null Hypothesis: The median of ARIMA RMSE = The median of MLP RMSE
#' Alternative Hypothesis: The median of ARIMA RMSE &lt;&gt; The median of MLP RMSE 
# 
#' @param x: Distribution 1 to compare
#' @param y: Distribution 2 to compare

wtest = function(x,y){
  col_list = colnames(x)[grepl('RMSE',colnames(x))]
  horizon_list = as.numeric(gsub('RMSE_', &quot;&quot;, col_list))
  
  empty_matrix = matrix(ncol = 0, nrow =length(col_list))
  wtest_df = data.frame(empty_matrix)
  
  wtest_df['horizon'] = horizon_list
  wtest = numeric(length(col_list))
  
  for (c in col_list) {
    wtest[[c]] = wilcox.test(unlist(x[c]), unlist(y[c]), alternative = 'two.sided')$p.value
    }
  wtest_df['pvalue'] = list(wtest[sapply(wtest, function(x) x == 0 )==FALSE])
  ?wilcox.test
  for (rn in 1:nrow(wtest_df)) {
  if (wtest_df[rn,'pvalue'] &gt; 0.05) 
    {
    print(paste('Fail to reject the Null Hypothesis: There is not enough evidence at alpha = 0.05 level of significance (p-value: ', wtest_df[rn,'pvalue'], ') to suggest that the median of ARMIA RMSE for horizon: ',wtest_df[rn,'horizon'], 'is different than the median of MLP RMSE.'))
    
  }
  else {
    print(paste('Reject the Null Hypothesis: There is sufficient evidence at alpha = 0.05 level of significance (p-value: ', wtest_df[rn,'pvalue'], ') to suggest that the median of ARMIA RMSE for horizon: ',wtest_df[rn,'horizon'], 'is different than the median of MLP RMSE.'))}
}
  
  return(wtest_df)
}"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' This function computes a Wilcoxon hypothesis test between ARIMA/ARMA and MLP RMSE distributions to see if the forecast errors are significant or not. </span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' Null Hypothesis: The median of ARIMA RMSE = The median of MLP RMSE</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' Alternative Hypothesis: The median of ARIMA RMSE &lt;&gt; The median of MLP RMSE </span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> </span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param x: Distribution 1 to compare</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>' @param y: Distribution 2 to compare</span>

<span class="pl-en">wtest</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>,<span class="pl-smi">y</span>){
  <span class="pl-v">col_list</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> colnames(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)[grepl(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>RMSE<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,colnames(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>))]
  <span class="pl-v">horizon_list</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> as.numeric(gsub(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>RMSE_<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">col_list</span>))
  
  <span class="pl-v">empty_matrix</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">matrix</span>(<span class="pl-v">ncol</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span>, <span class="pl-v">nrow</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>length(<span class="pl-smi">col_list</span>))
  <span class="pl-v">wtest_df</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">data.frame</span>(<span class="pl-smi">empty_matrix</span>)
  
  <span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>horizon<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">horizon_list</span>
  <span class="pl-v">wtest</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">numeric</span>(length(<span class="pl-smi">col_list</span>))
  
  <span class="pl-k">for</span> (<span class="pl-smi">c</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-smi">col_list</span>) {
    <span class="pl-smi">wtest</span>[[<span class="pl-smi">c</span>]] <span class="pl-k">=</span> wilcox.test(unlist(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>[<span class="pl-smi">c</span>]), unlist(<span class="pl-smi">y</span>[<span class="pl-smi">c</span>]), <span class="pl-v">alternative</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>two.sided<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">p.value</span>
    }
  <span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>pvalue<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">list</span>(<span class="pl-smi">wtest</span>[sapply(<span class="pl-smi">wtest</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-smi">x</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span> )<span class="pl-k">==</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>])
  ?<span class="pl-smi">wilcox.test</span>
  <span class="pl-k">for</span> (<span class="pl-smi">rn</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span>nrow(<span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>)) {
  <span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-smi">rn</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>pvalue<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>] <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.05</span>) 
    {
    print(paste(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Fail to reject the Null Hypothesis: There is not enough evidence at alpha = 0.05 level of significance (p-value: <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-smi">rn</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>pvalue<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>], <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>) to suggest that the median of ARMIA RMSE for horizon: <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,<span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-smi">rn</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>horizon<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>], <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>is different than the median of MLP RMSE.<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))
    
  }
  <span class="pl-k">else</span> {
    print(paste(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Reject the Null Hypothesis: There is sufficient evidence at alpha = 0.05 level of significance (p-value: <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-smi">rn</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>pvalue<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>], <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>) to suggest that the median of ARMIA RMSE for horizon: <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,<span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>[<span class="pl-smi">rn</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>horizon<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>], <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>is different than the median of MLP RMSE.<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))}
}
  
  <span class="pl-k">return</span>(<span class="pl-smi">wtest_df</span>)
}</pre></div>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-monthly-demographic-data-computation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#monthly-demographic-data-computation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Monthly Demographic Data computation</h1>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

m_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(MDM3, f=12, horizon = c(3,6,18))
m_mlp = roll.win.mlp(MDM3, f=12, horizon = c(3,6,18))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>
<span class="pl-v">start.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()

<span class="pl-v">m_arima</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.auto_arima(<span class="pl-smi">MDM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">12</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">6</span>,<span class="pl-c1">18</span>))
<span class="pl-v">m_mlp</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.mlp(<span class="pl-smi">MDM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">12</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">6</span>,<span class="pl-c1">18</span>))

<span class="pl-v">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()
<span class="pl-v">wall.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">start.time</span>
print(paste(<span class="pl-smi">wall.time</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))</pre></div>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-quarterly-demographic-data-computation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#quarterly-demographic-data-computation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Quarterly Demographic Data computation</h1>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

q_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(QDM3, f=4, horizon = c(1,3,8))
q_mlp = roll.win.mlp(QDM3, f=4, horizon = c(1,3,8))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>
<span class="pl-v">start.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()

<span class="pl-v">q_arima</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.auto_arima(<span class="pl-smi">QDM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>))
<span class="pl-v">q_mlp</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.mlp(<span class="pl-smi">QDM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>))

<span class="pl-v">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()
<span class="pl-v">wall.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">start.time</span>
print(paste(<span class="pl-smi">wall.time</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))</pre></div>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-yearly-demographic-data-computation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#yearly-demographic-data-computation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Yearly Demographic Data computation</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

y_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(YDM3, f=1, horizon = c(1,3,6))
y_mlp = roll.win.mlp(YDM3, f=1, horizon = c(1,3,6))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>
<span class="pl-v">start.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()

<p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/ttoth76/arima_vs_mlp/blob/main/ds_6373_project_files/figure-gfm/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png"><img src="/ttoth76/arima_vs_mlp/raw/main/ds_6373_project_files/figure-gfm/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png" width="100%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/ttoth76/arima_vs_mlp/blob/main/ds_6373_project_files/figure-gfm/unnamed-chunk-18-2.png"><img src="/ttoth76/arima_vs_mlp/raw/main/ds_6373_project_files/figure-gfm/unnamed-chunk-18-2.png" width="100%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-demographic-data-comparision-conclusions" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#demographic-data-comparision-conclusions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Demographic Data Comparision Conclusions</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Three method was used for the comparison between the ARIMA/ARMA and
MLP models. Each method was applied to each time period in the M3 data
set (Monthly, Quarterly, Yearly).
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Forecasting with Rolling window estimation using RMSE and SMAPE as
error metrics. Defined a longer rolling window size (50% of the
realization) for smoother estimates. Shorter window sizes may not
provide enough data points to identify important time series
characteristics like trend or seasonality. For each rolling window
subsample we estimated a model and then computed the RMSE for each
step ahead forecast. The final RMSE value is the mean of each
step-ahead subsample RMSE.</li>
<li>Forecast without rolling windows. This method simply subtracts the
length of the horizon from the data set to create a training set.
The reminder of the data will be used as a test set to help
calculating RMSE and SMAPE.</li>
<li>Ensemble of models per horizon.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The comparison was made based on visual inspection and descriptive
statistics of the RMSE and SMPAE distributions.
<ul dir="auto">
<li>The first plot combines all the estimated ARIMA/ARMA and MLP models
with all the forecast horizon and RMSE and SMAPE values. This type
of plot enables us to compare the overall performance of the models.</li>
<li>The second plot is a <code>facet grid</code> which segregates the performance
plot by forecast horizon. This plot enables us to compare the MLP
and ARMIA/ARMA models on a more granular level but using a shared
y-axis.</li>
<li>The same plots were drawn again with the RMSE values being Log()
scaled. This plot was built because the forecast errors range
between very low and very high values making the visual inspection
more difficult. The log transformation brings the data into the same
scale so we can better visualize the RMSE values. The SMAPE values
are percentages therefore no scaling is required for those.</li>
<li>Descriptive statistics is calculated for each computation of RMSE
and SMAPE values to enable quantitative comparison of the
distributions.</li>
<li>Also used a non-parametric Wilcoxon rank sum test to compare whether
the median RMSE of ARIMA/ARMA models per horizon is significantly
different from the median RMSE of the MLP models per horizon. This
test is violating the independence of observations due to the
overlap in the rolling window method but may represent a valid test
for the non-rolling window tests.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Monthly time interval</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">On the monthly data set we can observe that for Horizon = 3 and 6 both
ARIMA/ARMA and MLP models are performing very similarly. The first
~70 estimated models have very low RMSE and SMAPE values indicating
that both ARIMA and MLP were able to equally well forecast on these
data sets.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Large RMSE and SMAPE peaks can be seen above model #70 therefore the
models were not able to well estimate these data sets. These large
peaks in the plot is due to the characteristic of the data that the
model was not able to explain properly. The ARIMA models were
performing worse then the MLP models at model #89-90 for horizon 3
and 6. On the other hand, the ARIMA models outperformed the MLP models
for long-term forecast (h=18) nearly for all realizations in the data
set.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Comparing the model performances with and without rolling windows we
can make an interesting observation that the rolling window method
significantly improved the forecast performance of the MLP models for
short (3) and medium (6) term horizons. The long-term (h=18) MLP
forecast performance however is better without rolling window
calculation. ARIMA models seem to perform better with rolling windows
forecast estimations for all horizons in this test.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">In general, we can conclude that as the forecast horizon is increasing
the forecast error is increasing with it regardless of the type of the
model (ARIMA or MLP).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The ensemble plot shows that the ARIMA models outperformed the MLP
models at all horizon values. This means that if fit an ensemble of
ARIMA models to the combined realizations then its forecast
performance will be superior to the MLP models.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The Wilcoxon hypothesis tests underpins the visual assessment that no
statistically significant difference can be observed between the
Median RMSE of ARIMA/ARMA models and the Median RMSE of MLP models per
horizon.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Quarterly time interval</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">The Quarterly data have fewer realizations and data points per
realization then of the monthly data.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">On the Quarterly data we can observe very similar behavior as we have
seen on the Monthly data.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The MLP model has a better performance on the short-term horizon
forecast.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The ARIMA models performs better on long-term horizon forecasts (h=8)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The max RMSE value is smaller then it is of the monthly data. This is
not a surprise as Demographic data has a quarterly seasonality in
practice which is apparent here.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The non-rolling window method shows a decrease in forecast accuracy
performance for MLP and ARIMA models as well. The increase in forecast
error is more pronounced for the MLP models though especially in the
long-term horizon.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Ensemble performance is very similar to the monthly data set however
the error difference is narrower at horizon 2 than it is for the
monthly realizations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">There is a steep increase in RMSE value at horizon 6 in the ensemble
plot. We can also see a similar steep increase in error on the SMAPE
plot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The Wilcoxon hypothesis tests underpins the visual assessment that no
statistically significant difference can be observed between the
Median RMSE of ARIMA/ARMA models and the Median RMSE of MLP models per
horizon.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Yearly time interval</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">The yearly data set has more realizations but shorter time horizons in
each realizations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The forecast errors are more pronounced at shorter-term horizons which
is due to the granularity of the data.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Just by visual inspection it seems that both models are performing
very similarly regardless of the horizon. The MLP model seem to handle
outliers a bit better in the data set and outperformed the ARIMA
models at the peaks.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The rolling window forecast method performs significantly better for
both ARIMA/ARMA and MLP models regardless of the forecast horizon.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Ensemble model behavior is exactly the same as what we have seen
earlier.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The Wilcoxon hypothesis tests underpins the visual assessment that no
statistically significant difference can be observed between the
Median RMSE of ARIMA/ARMA models and the Median RMSE of MLP models per
horizon.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto"><strong>General observations of Demographic data experiment</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">The RMSE and SMAPE metrics showed consistent model performance trends
in the experiments. Both metrics had peaks and valleys at the same
realization.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">No clear evidence that the ARIMA model outperformed the MLP model or
vice versa on the Demographic data set. Both type of models performed
very similarly for almost all time intervals, realizations in the data
set. ARIMA however showed slightly better performance on the monthly
data set when forecasting out 18 months. In other words the ARIMA
model is more suited for long-term forecast then the MLP model.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The model performances are dependent on the length of the forecast
horizon, as the length is increasing the forecast error is also
increasing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The time interval of the data (Monthly, Quarterly, Yearly) has impact
on the forecast performance as well. For the same forecast horizon the
mean RMSE is lower for the monthly data than it is for the yearly
data.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The test shows that complex models like MLP does not produce a more
accurate or stable result than an auto.arima() function. Neural
networks are not great at modeling trends therefore trend components
needs to be removed from the data prior to modeling. Our method let
the MLP() function to decide automatically on the trend factors which
may be a disadvantage for the MLP model. The neural network may have
performed better if upfront model ID was done for each time series
realization.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Neural Network models are computationally intensive methods compared
to the more simpler ARIMA models therefore if computational power is a
constraints then ARIMA models are the way to go as they perform well
and takes less time to train them. Just for the Demography data,
training MLP models took &gt;7 hours. (computation time is printed after
the relevant chunks)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-monthly-micro-data-computation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#monthly-micro-data-computation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Monthly Micro Data computation</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

kl.m_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(MMM3, f=12, horizon = c(3,6,18))
kl.m_mlp = roll.win.mlp(MMM3, f=12, horizon = c(3,6,18))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-quarterly-micro-data-computation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#quarterly-micro-data-computation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Quarterly Micro Data computation</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

kl.q_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(QMM3, f=4, horizon = c(1,3,8))
kl.q_mlp = roll.win.mlp(QMM3, f=4, horizon = c(1,3,8))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>
<span class="pl-v">start.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()

<span class="pl-v">kl.q_arima</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.auto_arima(<span class="pl-smi">QMM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>))
<span class="pl-v">kl.q_mlp</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.mlp(<span class="pl-smi">QMM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>))

<span class="pl-v">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()
<span class="pl-v">wall.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">start.time</span>
print(paste(<span class="pl-smi">wall.time</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))</pre></div>

(summary(<span class="pl-k">data.frame</span>(lapply(<span class="pl-smi">kl.y_mlp_no_roll</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">dataframe</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) unlist(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)))))

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-micro-data-comparisionconclusions" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#micro-data-comparisionconclusions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Micro Data ComparisionConclusions</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Monthly Data:</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">The SMAPE and RMSE error metrics were compared for ARIMA and MLP
models, at horizon lengths of 3, 6, and 18 to evaluate monthly
forecasting performance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Upon visual inspection using the Faceted ARIMA vs. MLP Model
Performance plots, MLP and ARIMA models appear to perform similarly at
horizon lengths of 3 and 6. However, the MLP model appears to have
higher RMSE and SMAPE values at a horizon of 18. This suggests that
ARIMA models may be more useful for forecasting monthly Micro data at
longer horizon lengths.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Next, the summary statistics of the Rolling Window RMSE and SMAPE
values were evaluated. The median RMSE and SMAPE values increased as
horizon length increased for both ARIMA and MLP models. In addition,
the MLP models had higher RMSE and SMAPE values across each horizon
compared to the ARIMA models. This was most extreme at horizon length
18.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Quarterly Data:</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">The SMAPE and RMSE error metrics were compared for ARIMA and MLP
models at horizon lengths of 1, 3, and 8 to evaluate quarterly
forecasting performance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Upon visual inspection using the Faceted ARIMA vs. MLP Model
Performance plots, MLP and ARIMA models appear to perform similarly at
horizon lengths of 1 and 3. However, the MLP model appears to have
higher RMSE and SMAPE values at a horizon of 8. This suggests that
ARIMA models may be more useful for forecasting quarterly Micro data
at longer horizon lengths.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Next, the summary statistics of the Rolling Window RMSE and SMAPE
values were evaluated. The median RMSE and SMAPE values increased as
horizon length increased for both ARIMA and MLP models. In addition,
the MLP models had higher RMSE and SMAPE values across each horizon
length compared to the ARIMA models. The ARIMA and MLP models had
similar RMSE and SMAPE values at horizon length 1; however, at
horizons 3 and 8, the ARIMA model yielded lower SMAPE and RMSE values.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Using the summary statistics and the information from the RMSE and
SMAPE plots, there is strong evidence to suggest that ARIMA models
provided more useful forecasts than MLP models at a long horizon
length for both monthly and quarterly data. For shorter horizon
lengths, there was no strong visual evidence suggesting a model with
better forecasting performance; however, the median rolling window
RMSE and SMAPE values were lower overall for the ARIMA models. In
addition, the ensemble plot shows that the ARIMA models outperformed
the MLP models at all horizon values. Therefore, an ARIMA model is
suggested over an MLP model for more useful forecasts.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Yearly Data:</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">The SMAPE and RMSE error metrics were compared for ARIMA and MLP
models at horizon lengths of 1, 3, and 6 to evaluate yearly
forecasting performance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Upon visual inspection using the Faceted ARIMA vs. MLP Model
Performance plots, ARIMA models appeared to yield lower RMSE and SMAPE
values at each horizon length. This suggests that ARIMA models may be
more useful for forecasting yearly Micro data, regardless of horizon
length.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Next, the summary statistics of the Rolling Window RMSE and SMAPE
values were evaluated. The median RMSE and SMAPE values increased as
horizon length increased for both ARIMA and MLP models. In addition,
the MLP models had higher RMSE and SMAPE values across each horizon
length compared to the ARIMA models. The ARIMA model yielded lower
SMAPE and RMSE values across all horizons.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Using the summary statistics and the information from the RMSE and
SMAPE plots, there is strong evidence to suggest that ARIMA models
provide more useful forecasts than MLP models at each horizon length
for yearly data. In addition, the ensemble plot shows that the ARIMA
models outperformed the MLP models at all horizon values. Therefore, I
would suggest selecting an ARIMA model over an MLP model for more
useful yearly Micro forecasts.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###

dg.m_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(MFM3, f=12, horizon = c(3,6,18))
dg.m_mlp = roll.win.mlp(MFM3, f=12, horizon = c(3,6,18))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>

<span class="pl-v">dg.m_arima</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.auto_arima(<span class="pl-smi">MFM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">12</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">6</span>,<span class="pl-c1">18</span>))
<span class="pl-v">dg.m_mlp</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.mlp(<span class="pl-smi">MFM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">12</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">6</span>,<span class="pl-c1">18</span>))

<span class="pl-v">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()
<span class="pl-v">wall.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">start.time</span>
print(paste(<span class="pl-smi">wall.time</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))</pre></div>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

dg.q_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(QFM3, f=4, horizon = c(1,3,8))
dg.q_mlp = roll.win.mlp(QFM3, f=4, horizon = c(1,3,8))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>
<span class="pl-v">start.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()

<span class="pl-v">dg.q_arima</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.auto_arima(<span class="pl-smi">QFM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>))
<span class="pl-v">dg.q_mlp</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> roll.win.mlp(<span class="pl-smi">QFM3</span>, <span class="pl-v">f</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>, <span class="pl-v">horizon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>))

<span class="pl-v">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> Sys.time()
<span class="pl-v">wall.time</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">end.time</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span> <span class="pl-smi">start.time</span>
print(paste(<span class="pl-smi">wall.time</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))</pre></div>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-yearly-finance-data-computation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#yearly-finance-data-computation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Yearly Finance Data computation</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-r notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="### Rolling Windows computations ###
start.time = Sys.time()

dg.y_arima = roll.win.auto_arima(YFM3, f=1, horizon = c(1,3,6))
dg.y_mlp = roll.win.mlp(YFM3, f=1, horizon = c(1,3,6))

end.time = Sys.time()
wall.time = end.time - start.time
print(paste(wall.time, 'between start and end of computation (time it took to compute the Time Series estiomations).'))"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span>## Rolling Windows computations ###</span>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-finance-data-conclusions" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#finance-data-conclusions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Finance Data Conclusions</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li></li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-category-comparison" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#category-comparison"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Category Comparison</h1>
<p dir="auto">#####################################################################################</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">In conclusion, the MLP and ARIMA models’ RMSE and SMAPE increased as
horizon length increased for all three data categories. Therefore
suggesting that as horizon length increases, forecasting performance
decreases.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">For the demographic data, there is no strong evidence suggesting that
MLP or ARIMA models performed better. However, it is important to
consider the computation power available. MLP is computationally
intensive. If computation power is limited, an ARIMA model is
suggested for forecasting. On the other hand, for finance and micro
categories, ARIMA models yielded better forecasting performance than
MLP models.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">With respect to data type (quarterly, monthly, and yearly data), the
micro and demographic categories had the best forecasting performance
using quarterly data. In contrast, the finance category had the best
forecasting performance using monthly data.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</article>
